answers.author: Pamela Caskie
answers.text:
First, remember your ethical responsibility to your current employer.  ICMA ethics obligates you to at least 2 years with any employer unless your employer makes a different decision.  Get involved in NCMA in any way your current manager will let you.  They have an excellent relationship with UNO for continuing education and a master's degree.  I would suggest that if you want to be a city manager in a larger community, a master degree is a must but be patient because all the education in the world won't make up for the experience your will get in small town America in the beginning of your career.  Good luck.

answers.author: Peter Olson
answers.text:
I'd echo Pamela's comments as a graduate of UNO and as a former manager in Nebraska, the "education" I received in a small community helps guide my outlook on larger scale. I'd also recommend you talk with Lowell about your desire's, he will be able to provide some work experience that is going to help with the resume and some guidance, as a "young" manager I am (probably should be was) always looking for the mentor relationship for people that I could call and ask a question.  The ICMA emerging leaders program, helped with that, but even now I try to find that "veteran" manager in the state organization that is willing to help mentor.   A last note, I'm probably infering, but remember bigger isn't better.

answers.author: Michael Bridges
answers.text:
After following all of the advice of the other responders, there are two paths to becoming a city manager in a large city. One is to become a city manager in a small city and then in due time move to larger cities. The other way is to move to a large city and work your way up that organization. But working in a small city gives you broader hands-on experience and you may find that you will really enjoy working and living in a small city.

answers.author: Zane Reynolds
answers.text:
You are getting much better expiriance working as an assistant than you will in ANY master's program. I have a master's from a fairly high ranking school in Washington DC and I am finding it difficult to get even an entry level job as a budget analyst in any jurisdiction. 
If you do decide to get a master's, make sure you can keep persuing your expiriance there in Nebraska. Also, dont spend a whole lot on the degree. With expiriance as an assistant, the reputation of the institution will not matter all that much.
